senses.de: The quality of being good or worthy of to be praised or rewarded
senses.ex: Her virtues are of more merit than her beauty.

Tips.title: Praise Worthiness
Tips.description: Use 'merit' when something is so good that it deserves recognition or reward.
Tips.example: His innovative research merits the highest award.

Tips.title: Subjective Assessment
Tips.description: 'Merit' often involves personal judgment; what one person sees as merit, another may not.
Tips.example: Whether modern art has merit can be a matter of personal taste.

senses.de: A good feature or point that someone or something has
senses.ex: The film has its merits, but is not brilliant.

Tips.title: Acknowledging Quality
Tips.description: Highlight a positive aspect of something when its overall worth is uncertain.
Tips.example: This plan has the merit of being straightforward and easy to implement.

Tips.title: Objectivity
Tips.description: Mention 'merits' to discuss good points in a balanced way, without bias.
Tips.example: We should consider the merits of each application objectively.

senses.de: To deserve to be given or done something
senses.ex: His hard work merits a higher position.

Tips.title: Deserved Recognition
Tips.description: Emphasize that someone has rightfully earned something due to their actions or qualities.
Tips.example: She merits a promotion after years of dedicated service.

Tips.title: Impartiality
Tips.description: Use the verb form to suggest fairness, where decisions are based on achievement, not favoritism.
Tips.example: Awards should be granted to those who merit them, regardless of their background.

senses.de: A system in which value points are given for good behavior or performance
senses.ex: You need 10 merit points to be eligible for the award.

Tips.title: Motivational Tool
Tips.description: Understand 'merit' as a system to encourage good behavior or work, especially in educational settings.
Tips.example: Students earn merit points for submitting homework on time.

Tips.title: Quantified Achievement
Tips.description: In specific contexts like education, 'merit' can be concrete, with measurable rewards.
Tips.example: He collected enough merit points for a free lunch at the cafeteria.

Ability.wordDefinition:
Ability refers to someone's inherent skill or talent to perform a certain task or activity. This means that a person has the potential to do something well.

For example, a person may have the ability to play basketball due to their height and coordination.

In terms of where each word is applicable, ability is more commonly used to describe someone's natural talents or potential.

Achievement.wordDefinition:
Achievement refers to the accomplishment of a goal or task.

It is typically used to describe something that one has worked hard to attain. For example, getting an "A" on a difficult exam would be considered an achievement.

Achievement is something that is earned through hard work, while merit is something that is recognized based on a person's inherent qualities.

Excellence.wordDefinition:
Excellence refers to possessing outstanding qualities or abilities in a particular field or activity. It implies going above and beyond the average or expected standard.

Excellence is applicable in areas where exceptional performance is highly valued, such as in academics, sports, business, or the arts.

In simpler terms, excellence is about being exceptional and standing out, while merit is about being recognized and rewarded for doing well.

Quality.wordDefinition:
Quality refers to the degree of excellence or superiority of something.

It is often used when evaluating the performance or characteristics of a product, service, or experience. For example, if a restaurant serves high-quality food, the ingredients may be fresh and the dishes well-prepared.

Merit is typically used when discussing an individual's value or worth, while quality is used when evaluating the level of excellence or superiority of a product or experience.

Talent.wordDefinition:
Talent refers to a natural ability or aptitude for a particular skill or activity. It is applicable in situations where one's innate abilities or potential are considered.

For example, a person who has a knack for playing the guitar has a talent for music.

Merit is based on effort and achievement, while talent is based on natural ability. Both terms are important in different areas of life and can be developed with practice and dedication.

Value.wordDefinition:
Value refers to the worth or significance given to an object, idea, or behavior. It is a subjective concept that varies from person to person and from situation to situation.

Value can be based on factors such as utility, beauty, morality, or personal preference.

Merit is about earning recognition or reward based on one's qualities and achievements, while value is about assigning worth or importance to something based on personal judgment or cultural norms.

Virtue.wordDefinition:
Virtue refers to a moral or ethical quality that is considered to be good or desirable. It is applicable to situations where someone displays good character, integrity, or honesty.

Virtue is not about achieving something, but rather about how a person conducts themselves and how they treat others.

So, in simple terms, merit is about achieving something and being recognized for it, while virtue is about being a good person and doing the right thing.

Worth.wordDefinition:
Worth refers to the value that something or someone has, either in terms of money or importance. For example, a diamond might have a high monetary worth because it is rare and valuable, or a person might be considered worth a lot to their family because they provide emotional support and care.

To put it simply, merit is about the qualities and abilities someone has, while worth is about the value or importance of something or someone.
